awd_titl_txt: SBP: A Perfect Match?  How Job Demands Shape Gender and Minority Differences in Hiring
awd_abstract_narration:
Continued status differences in occupational attainment prompt concerns regarding whether and to what extent such differences are a function of bias in the hiring process.  A critical point in this process is when job applicants either do or do not receive call backs—request for interviews or more information—after applications have been submitted, and whether such differences vary by social status.  This project will examine whether and how job demands – the required skills and expectations associated with a job opening – influence gender and racial differences in offering callbacks. The project will examine whether employers are more or less likely to decline callbacks for women and minority job applicants when the job demands are vague vs. quantified, feminine-typed vs. masculine-typed, and when applicants meet or do not meet the required job demands. The project will additionally examine how such patterns, and the association with job demands, depend on job level and upward vs. downward job mobility.  Biases faced by women and minorities are costly, not only to the applicants but to companies and the broader economy that may be missing out on matching talented individuals to appropriate jobs. By elucidating the specific mechanisms and conditions under which biases occurs, this research will demonstrate how interventions by employers and government leaders can reduce inequality in the labor market.

To study how job demands affect gender and racial inequality levels, and how demands relate to bias across job level and upward or downward job mobility, the project will field a large-scale audit study. This field experiment study will involve varying applicants by perceived race and gender, signaled by name. The project will submit approximately 20,000 job applications to online job openings, recording callbacks – requests for interviews or more information – across experimental condition. The scope conditions will be limited to four occupations: accountants, software engineers, sales professionals, and human resource managers. Approximately 5,000 job applications will be submitted to each occupation, dividing applications between entry-level and mid-level positions, and between applicants who are in early- or mid-career stages to represent attempts at upward vs. downward job mobility. The job openings in the audit study will then be matched to proprietary skill data on online job postings. By merging these data, the project will identify and characterize the bundle of job demands for each unique job opening. Computational text analysis techniques such as topic models, together with information in the dataset, will be used to create variables to categorize demands by level of vagueness, associations of masculinity or femininity, and the extent to which applicants meet the demands. Logistic regression models predicting callbacks will be used, modeling interaction effects with the job demand variables and applicants’ race and gender.  The project will assess whether and how job demands affect bias within occupations and job level, and whether demands mediate the relationship between bias and job mobility. Findings will inform sociological theories regarding status differences in the operation of labor markets, particularly for professional occupations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The U.S. labor market is a site of gender and racial inequality across occupations and job level within occupation, and existing research has shown that bias in hiring screening decisions is one source of such inequality: women and minority racial/ethnic groups face disadvantages in hiring screening outcomes even when job candidates are equivalent on paper. Yet, less is known as to how gender and racial biases in hiring decisions vary across factors associated with the job applicant and the position sought?including the job level of the applicant and position, as well as the skills the applicant holds compared to the job?s required demands. In this study, we examine how job applicants? gender and race affects inequality in callback rates, and the extent to which employers' biases in hiring screening decisions vary across characteristics of the applicant and job. To do so, we collected data with the support of a team of graduate and undergraduate research assistants, using a large-scale correspondence audit study of employers across several occupations, for fictitious White women, White men, African-American women and African-American men applicants. The audit study design, with additional analyses of the jobs? requirements, allows us to compare variation in the extent of hiring screening bias across applicants? skills and the job?s demands, such as the applicant?s level of experience compared to the job?s required experience. We also studied variation in bias across job mobility, for example considering applicants who seek a higher-level job compared to the same-level position that they currently hold. Additionally, because our data collection period for our accountant audit study occurred during the COVID-19 pandemic, we were able to explore variation in patterns of bias as the labor market context changed.


The project makes several advancements in our knowledge of the extent of gender and racial inequality at the point of hire. First, we find that the extent of bias in advantage of White men applicants differs across the applicant?s match to the job requirements, with less bias evident when applicants closely match the job?s demands, such as experience, and greater bias when the applicant is further away from the job?s demands. Second, we find that patterns of callbacks vary across the job level of the applicant and position. For example, in software engineering, we find that White women, Black men, and Black women applying to early-career positions face discrimination relative to White men, but when applying upwardly to senior positions we find no preference in callbacks for White men and White women applicants received higher callbacks than other groups. We connect these findings to the pressure to increase gender and racial diversity in this occupational context, especially for higher-level jobs, which affects the callback patterns and different outcomes for applicants of different combined gender and race statuses. Third, we examined how the disruption to labor markets caused by the COVID-19 pandemic affected patterns of hiring screening decisions before the pandemic and during the early pandemic period, and examined geographic variation in these patterns. We find that discrimination patterns among accountants changed during the early pandemic period: women?especially White women?had relatively higher callback rates during the pandemic compared to before, and this change is concentrated in geographic areas where women left the labor market at higher rates. These findings, together with future and ongoing projects using these data, help to illustrate how the extent of gender and racial discrimination in hiring varies across features of the applicant and the job. The project offers insights into how patterns of inequality in initial hiring decisions across gender and race are heightened or reduced depending on the occupational context, the applicant and job match, and the broader labor market context, which helps to inform how interventions by employers or government leaders can effectively reduce inequality in hiring decisions in the labor market.
